Generation I.Red: Lives about one yard underground where it feeds on plant roots. It sometimes appears above ground.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: Lives about one yard underground where it feeds on plant roots. It sometimes appears above ground.
Generation I.Yellow: It prefers dark places. It spends most of its time underground, though it may pop up in caves.
Generation I.Stadium: Its head pokes up approximately eight inches out of the ground. However, its real size remains a mystery to this day.

Generation II.Gold: Its skin is very thin. If it is exposed to light, its blood heats up, causing it to grow weak.
Generation II.Silver: If a Diglett Digs through a field, it leaves the soil perfectly tilled and ideal for planting crops.
Generation II.Crystal: It digs underground and chews on tree roots, sticking its head out only when the sun isn't bright.
Generation II.Stadium 2: Its skin is very thin. If it is exposed to light, its blood heats up, causing it to grow weak. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) If a Diglett Dig s through a field, it leaves the soil perfectly tilled and ideal for planting crops. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: Diglett are raised in most farms. The reason is simple - wherever this Pok é mon burrows, the soil is left perfectly tilled for planting crops. This soil is made ideal for growing delicious vegetables.
Generation III.Sapphire: Diglett are raised in most farms. The reason is simple - wherever this Pok é mon burrows, the soil is left perfectly tilled for planting crops. This soil is made ideal for growing delicious vegetables.
Generation III.Emerald: Diglett are raised in most farms. The reason is simple--wherever they burrow, the soil is left perfectly tilled for growing delicious crops.
Generation III.FireRed: It burrows through the ground at a shallow depth. It leaves raised earth in its wake, making it easy to spot.
Generation III.LeafGreen: Lives about one yard underground where it feeds on plant roots. It sometimes appears aboveground.

Generation IV.Diamond: A Pokémon that lives underground. Because of its dark habitat, it is repelled by bright sunlight.
Generation IV.Pearl: A Pokémon that lives underground. Because of its dark habitat, it is repelled by bright sunlight.
Generation IV.Platinum: A Pokémon that lives underground. Because of its dark habitat, it is repelled by bright sunlight.
Generation IV.HeartGold: Its skin is very thin. If it is exposed to light, its blood heats up, causing it to grow weak.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: If a Diglett digs through a field, it leaves the soil perfectly tilled and ideal for planting crops.

Generation V.Black: A Pokémon that lives underground. Because of its dark habitat, it is repelled by bright sunlight.
Generation V.White: A Pokémon that lives underground. Because of its dark habitat, it is repelled by bright sunlight.
Generation V.Black 2: A Pokémon that lives underground. Because of its dark habitat, it is repelled by bright sunlight.
Generation V.White 2: A Pokémon that lives underground. Because of its dark habitat, it is repelled by bright sunlight.

Generation VI.X: Lives about one yard underground where it feeds on plant roots. It sometimes appears aboveground.
Generation VI.Y: Its skin is very thin. If it is exposed to light, its blood heats up, causing it to grow weak.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: Diglett are raised in most farms. The reason is simple— wherever this Pokémon burrows, the soil is left perfectly tilled for planting crops. This soil is made ideal for growing delicious vegetables.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: Diglett are raised in most farms. The reason is simple— wherever this Pokémon burrows, the soil is left perfectly tilled for planting crops. This soil is made ideal for growing delicious vegetables.

Generation VII.Sun: Its head sports an altered form of whiskers made of metal. When in communication with its comrades, its whiskers wobble to and fro.
Generation VII.Moon: Its golden hairs function as sensors. It pokes them out of its burrow to monitor its surroundings.
Generation VII.Ultra Sun: Although it's powerful enough to dig right through volcanic rock, it doesn't allow itself to be seen very often.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: The need to dig through volcanic rock in the ground has made them more powerful than the Diglett of other regions.
Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: After living in soil with high iron content for some time, three steel whiskers sprouted from the top of its head.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: After living in soil with high iron content for some time, three steel whiskers sprouted from the top of its head.

Generation VIII.Sword: The metal-rich geology of this Pokémon's habitat caused it to develop steel whiskers on its head.
Generation VIII.Shield: Its three hairs change shape depending on Diglett's mood. They're a useful communication tool among these Pokémon.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: This Pokémon lives underground. Because of its dark habitat, it is repelled by bright sunlight.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: This Pokémon lives underground. Because of its dark habitat, it is repelled by bright sunlight.

Generation IX.Scarlet: The things growing from its head are whiskers that have become metallic. Diglett communicates with its comrades by waving them.
Generation IX.Violet: Its golden whiskers function as sensors. It pokes them out of its burrow to monitor its surroundings.
